licence.p: Original text by Mary Shelley (1816). Public domain, under a CC-BY-NC 4.0 licence.

sourceDesc.p: Draft of Frankenstein, [August or September] – [?December] 1816. | Bodleian MS. Abinger c.56 (formerly designated Dep. 477/1) consists of 62 leaves originally bound in Notebook A, one of two now disbound notebooks in which Mary W. Shelley (MWS) drafted the two-volume version of Frankenstein. The draft in c.56 runs from the beginning to the end of Volume I, concluding just as the Creature is about to begin his tale to Victor.

up the curtain, and his eyes; ― Horizontal line above the text, unclear meaning. and his eyes; if eyes
they may be called, ― Horizontal line above the text, unclear meaning. were fixed on me – His
jaws opened and he muttered in some words
inarticulate sounds while a grin wrinkled his cheeks. He
might have spoken but I did not
hear — one had hand was stretched out
to detain me but I escaped and ran
rushed down the stairs case I took refuge in
a court-yard belonging to the house
which I inhabited; where I remained
duringthe rest of the night walking up and
down in the greatest agitation; listen
ing attentively, catching and fearing each
sound as if it were to announce the
arrival of the demoniacal corpse to
which I had so miserabl e y given life.

Oh! no mortal could support
the horror of that countenance.A
